awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Paul Apisa is "Teichmuller dynamics." The host institution for the fellowship is Yale University, and the sponsoring scientist is Yair Minsky.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most striking outcomes of this project involves billiards played on a table which, instead of being a rectangle, is a rational right triangle. Being “rational” means that all of the angles are a rational number of degrees. The result roughly counts the asymptotic number of periodic billiard trajectories, i.e. those that eventually repeat.

This result was the realization of a decades long program. To each rational polygonal billiard table there is an associated geometric object, called a translation surface, which is constructed from copies of the original table in a manner not dissimilar from the way in which gluing together six copies of a squares can make a cube. There is a general principle in rational billiards that, when confronted with a billiard problem, one should seek answers from the associated translation surface, which is called its unfolding.

The space of all translation surfaces admits a natural flow, i.e. a way to change one translation surface into another. The flow can be used to turn one translation surface into a family of translation surfaces, called an orbit closure. Over the decades, researchers have developed the following intricate process for answering counting problems in rational billiards. Start with a billiard table and form its unfolding, which is a translation surface. Take the translation surface and find its orbit closure. Finally, use numbers associated to the orbit closure, called Lyapunov exponents, to answer the original counting problem.

For this reason, counting periodic trajectories in right triangles was solved by studying orbit closures. In their Fields Medal and Breakthrough Prize winning work, Eskin and Mirzakhani showed that orbit closures, which at first glance might be jagged fractal sets, are actually smooth. Moreover, they have an important notion of size called rank. The rank is an integer that can range between 1 and g, where g is the genus of the translation surfaces, i.e. the number of holes that the surface has. A sphere has no holes, a donut has one hole, etc.

Orbit closures come in two flavors - easily understood ones that arise from geometry called branched covering constructions and everything else. Mirzakhani made the striking conjecture that any orbit closure of rank at least two is a branched covering construction. Wright and I confirmed Mirzakhani’s intuition by showing that if the rank of an orbit closure is at least g/2 + 1, where g is the number of holes the surface has, then the orbit closure is a branched covering construction. This project developed a vast new theory for understanding orbit closures and spanned nearly 300 pages.

While our work offers one of the most complete understandings of orbit closures in general, it was still not strong enough to answer the original counting problem for rational right triangles. To solve the counting problem, I noticed that the unfolding of right triangles have a little more symmetry than the typical translation surface (they belong to “low codimension hyperelliptic loci”) and then showed that Mirzakhani’s conjecture held exactly for such surfaces.

I also used these techniques  to study exceptionally symmetric translation surfaces called geminal ones, which occur in questions about the geometry of moduli space, a space that is very related to the space of translation surfaces.

With Bainbridge and Wang, I also studied the space of dilation surfaces, a slight generalization of a translation surface. Kontsevich conjectured that the space of translation surfaces can be easily understood geometrically, i.e. it is aspherical in the orbifold sense. My coauthors and I showed that when the space of translation surfaces is enlarged to include dilation surfaces, this conjecture is true.

One of the main components of the broader impacts of this project was directing three undergraduate research projects. The biggest was co-organizing the Summer@ICERM REU, in which my co-organizers and I created computational problems for 19 undergraduate students. The projects generated publicly available code that have already been used by researchers studying translation surfaces and also produced several publications which have been made available online and submitted for publication in journals. The previous summer I directed a graduate student and an undergraduate student at an REU that was organized at the University of Michigan. This project also resulted in a joint publication on billiards. Finally, with Chaya Norton, I organized a semester long research project for four undergraduates through the University of Michigan Laboratory of Geometry. The project was fundamentally computational and targeted to students who may have only seen linear algebra. The project resulted in publicly available code for performing computations on translation surfaces. During these projects I also created publicly accessible educational resources for undergraduates interested in conducting research on translation surfaces.

Finally, I mentored two graduate students by participating in a mentorship program through my home institution. I also delivered a public lecture on graph theory through Math Circles for highschoolers.
